transcripts.text: I think you've suggested that this whole S&C level and scandal, if you will, is Hollywood couldn't have written a better script.

Or a more convoluted one.  Nobody seems to be in charge over there.  They seem to be making decisions, they say, daily on what their message is going to be.  And it doesn't seem like a couple of days doesn't go by before somebody resigns.
Now, when you say over there, is that specifically the prime minister's office?

Yes.  I mean, I think a lot of liberal MPs and staffers are wondering, what's the message?  I think a few of them have been caught offside, maybe had been given some talking points which didn't play out so well, for example.  So there's been a lot of very confused messaging.  And of course, it's not, this isn't a story about messaging.  When you don't have a good story to tell, one suspects, that's when you have nine different stories.

How do you interpret, most recently we've seen Jodi Wilson-Raybould have these cabinet discussions or take part in a cabinet meeting?  I mean, are these secret meetings?  Are these typical cabinet meetings?  She's resigned.  And now she'll be called as a witness.

It's unusual to say the least for somebody who's left cabinet to then attend a cabinet meeting of the cabinet she's just left.  It's also unusual for a cabinet minister to resign and the first thing she does is lawyer up.  You know, hires a former Supreme Court Justice to advise her on what she can say and what she can't say.  It's also unusual for a cabinet minister to resign and not tell everybody exactly why she's resigning.  But there's a lot of unusual circumstances in this case.
translation a deal has been made?

I don't think anybody knows, and I frankly doubt it.  But who knows?  By all accounts, from people who know her well, she's a highly principled person.  I think if one is sort of reading the tea leaves of how people are positioning, it seems more than likely that she was the source of these allegations, anonymous allegations as they were when they were printed.  that somebody had pressured her to basically go easy on SNC-Lavalin.  So it would be unlikely if you were moved to resign your Cabinet seat over that.  It's hard to see how you then come back into Cabinet on any kind of deal, but we shall see.  But what I think everyone wants is to hear her side of the story.  We've been getting selective versions of it line by line from the Prime Minister on days that it suits him.  But we're obviously not going to get anything close to an understanding of the story until we hear from her.

A recent resignation also by the Prime Minister's top aide, Gerald Butts.  How do you interpret that?  Is that a pivot?  Don't look there.  There's nothing going on there.  Is that a pivot away from the Prime Minister?

Again, it's hard to know.  It's, again, very unusual for somebody to resign and say, but I have no reason to resign because I didn't do anything wrong.  Again, if you're trying to sort of work back the logic of this, you're not going to lose somebody of that stature in the government.  I mean, this is a very unusually central person in any government.  and unusually close to the Prime Minister.  So he wouldn't be going unless, I think, unless they anticipated some rather bad news to come.  And if you look at the kinds of things he said in his resignation letter where he talked about defending his reputation, he talked about people had accused him of being the person who had pressured her when I actually haven't seen his name being used specifically.  And when he talks about his relationship with Jody Wilson-Raybould, the former Attorney General, as having been close and supportive, You put all that together, it sounds like they're anticipating that Xi would say something about him having pressured her.  I don't know that for a fact, but just surmising from that.  And that is, I guess, the sort of thing that they didn't think they could survive in public relations terms.  He denies it, of course, and nobody can say for sure.  But it obviously wouldn't look good on the government, and that must have been part of the calculation.
